review_blob: Incredible aroma!  Overwhelming hops scent when opening bottle reminds you hops is of the Cannabis family.  Citrus taste is comparable to the best of this style.  Bell Two Hearted Ales Big Brother.

Not quite an Imperial, a solid entry in a tough category.  Typical SNB quality but not quite the splash I expected in  IBUs. Grapefruit dominates aroma with floral aftertaste  from the Cascades Im guessing.
Good hoppy character but like their IPA, a metallic aftertaste. Better choices out there in this catagory.
Hoopy character and Initial taste okay but metallic aftertaste. Similar to their Pale ale.
Spices in the on-bottle deScription in aroma but none noticable in taste. Some true pumpkin flavor. Slight warming sensationin aftertaste. Chewy seasonal. Decent Fall offering.
beer_name: Blue Moon Harvest Moon Pumpkin Ale

review_blob: Solid Imperial/Double.  Sweeter than most and not as bitter of a finish.  Citrusy.  Suprisingly the alcohol doesnt overwhelm even at 10 %.  Different yet in this case still good.
Malt aroma.  Some bite.  Major fault in the metallic finish.  Bad bottle?  Not seeing this complaint in others ratings.

Typical Dogfish quality.  Less hops  than their 60 or 90 minute IPAs.  Think Pizza minus  the usual hot peppers.  A lot of these ratings are low because they are expecting a 60 or 90 experience.  REMEMBER - This is a APA not a IPA. Please rate accordingly.   Great beer IN THIS STYLE.
Nice chewy Porter with smokey/roasted malt. Ends nicely with mellow finish.
Decent IPA although lacking the bang youve come to expect from todays "Hopheavy" ales. Lacks edge - moderate in everyway.  Plays it safe so......no guts no glory.
Big taste similar to their Red Rye - though more of a  toasted malt edge and much chewier. Good blend of hop bite and malt.  Nice departure from the norm.
Beautiful in appearance but lacking in depth of flavor.  Has the initial taste of an ESB but failed to follow thru from there. OK but nothing special.
Metallic, thin, fizzy & w/o much taste.  Was recommended!? He knew his beer but missed on this one big time.  Think Bud does Holland.

Dominant grapefruit upfront while lacking in finish.  Breadth without any depth. Good but not up there with Buckeye 76,  Dogfish Head 60 or 90 minute, Victory HopDevil or Bells IPA (or their suspiciously similar Two Hearted). Had in Bomber (22 oz).

Nothing bad but nothing exciting.  Falls into the wasteland of costing more than micros  but not as good as the crafts.  Not a APA really but good enough to drink if its this or the Miller or Bud boys.
UPDATED: JAN 2, 2006
Similar to the good LeftCoast IPAs like Stone and Sierra Nevada. Kindred in their use of floral hops while this tends to have just enough more IBUs to notice.  Solid entry in this style.
Think German Macro Dark Light. Better than Becks Dark (a Dunkel actually) but try Lakefront Eastside Dark (also a Dunkel but similar in where  the Reinheitsgebot boys wish they were).
Roasted flavor yet thin.  Bitter finish.  Average beer in this style.  Try Lakefront Eastside Dark for a superior Dunkel.
Thin metallic taste. "Best before" date still 5 months away so it isnt an age issue nor is refrigeration.   Sour, almost skunky smell.  To me Pils Urquell is the much better offering in this style.
Excellent IPA.  Although I had the 90 minute right after which made the 60 seem mild by comparison.  But in and of itself,  it is right up there with the top of this style.

Solid balanced taste with more of a bitter finish than most APAs - closer to a IPA I think. Hoppy throughout.  Highest rated APA? Id suggest Great Lakes Burning River or Sierra Nevada Pale or their Harvest Ale.

Slight floral initial taste leads into a bad (is there a good?)  metallic taste.  They use hard water but this was above that as a reason.  Bad batch?  I cant imagine all these good reviews if it always tastes this bad.  IPA is my preferred style so its not me.
Think Molson Export + marketing department = Molson Ice.  Standard Molson fare but with "cold brewed" visions.  No wonder Coors bought em. I would get it over US macros but Id stop there.
Maybe a little better than our macros but what this that really saying. Thin watery initial "taste" that disappates almost immediately.  Fails to finish.

Typical Canadian Macro - a little better than our Biggies but not close to a craft/macro.  Alcohol content was the big draw amongst my coworkers when going North since this only became available here in Ohio recently (due to 7.3%). Think Molson amped.

Average German Pils.  Not quite upto St. Pauli or Becks though they claim to import more to us than either. But with that way of thinking Miller and Bud are our best because of being our biggest exports?! Anyway this seemed a little light and lacking substance even for a pils.  Nothing bad per se, just nothing that gets your attention.

SNBs obvious attempt at attracting the lighter (in taste) drinkers out there. While most, if not all, of you reading this "get it" about the superiority of craft/micros, the $$$ is definately in making adjunkt (misspelling intentional) beer. SNB thought theyd try to appeal to those drinkers. While this is better than the macros, those same drinkers will stick to the stuff half the price. This is SNB Pale Ale Light in short.

Thanks to Jordan (Buck Dich) for the trade. I loved this Bitter!  In my opinion much better than its site score.  But that is why there are thousands of beers - to each his own.  Beautiful dark walnut color.  Malt present but hops still rules.  Best combination Ive had.  I hate malt dominance but a lot of IPAs and Bitters have no apparent malt at all.  This is like a 25/75 split.  Great bite in the rear ....uhhhh  I mean finish.
Thanks to Jordan (Buch Dich) for the trade.  One of the better amber ales. A definate middleweight lacking the substance of other ales.  Very good within its subcategory though.
Thanks to Jordan (Buck Dich) for trade.  Citric, almost sour aroma.  Similar taste without the floral finish of a lot of left coast IPAs.  Decent but try Two Hearted or Stones for  a better bitter.
Alefest 05 - Sorry to all the diehards.  This was more like a wine to me than an ale.  Not my style so please forgive my opinion.  Too sweet and too much of the coriander (for me).
Alefest 05  -  Standard issue.  Grainy flavor in an otherwise melancholy blandness.
Alefest 05 - Good solid IPA. Flowery bitterness in the finish.  Less malt than many of this style.
Alefest 05 - Solid entry in this style.  Good flowery bitterness from the hops. Close to a IPA in IBUs.
Alefest 05  - Just okay IPA. Didnt stand up to the others of this style at the festival. Medium body with slight malt, medium hops palate.
Alefest 05  -  Fairly mild Bitter.  Balanced but thin in both hops and malt.  Average not ES(pecial)B.
Alefest 05 - Somewhat disappointing entry of this style.  More thin and flat than our IPAs - closer to a english bittter or pale ale.
Alefest 05  - Big opening with thick malty front end.  Thinner without any statement in the the finish.  Not untypical ending of British ales.

Alefest 05 - 100+ IBU!!!!! This and Buckeye 76 at this festival combined to outduel the combination of most of my other samples IBUs!  Near perfect product as expected from one of the excellent breweries out there!
Alefest 05 - Wham with the right hand! One hoppy SOB. Quality from start to finish. Right there with Stones Ruination IPA!
Alefest 05  -  Average for this style.  More thin than those superior beers from Sierra Nevade, Three Floyds, and Stone.

Alefest 05 - An excellent Bitter.  Second best "new" beer at event (not including ones tried before).  Probably best Brit ESB Ive had. Most are more thin and flat than this.  More like our (US) Bitters.
Alefest 05  -  Good solid beer for this style. Fuller flavor than most pilsners.  Try their Hop Devil for an even better experience.
Alefest 05  - Winey, yeasty flavor. Not my cup of tea or beer for that matter. Too sweet.  Havent acquired that Belgium connection yet.
ALEFEST 05  Great IPA.  One of the top five of this style Ive had.  Best beer at the Festival. Soft yet full flavor.  Great hops finish!
Flat , thin palate especially for this style -although British bitters do tend have lower IBUs.  Hops fails to show its face.  I like our (US) ESBs better than this.
beer_name: Black Sheep Monty Pythons Holy Grail (Bottle)

review_blob:
Not ususally my style so dont judge this particular beer on my comments.  Definately a heavy handed brew.  Taste not much different than drinking a 50/50
blend of scotch and a strong ale.  Im much fonder of their Red Rye.  Apologies  to my two Scot grandfathers.

This was one of those beers that you didnt know what to expect from the deScription.  I found it to be very well balanced and not as malt heavy as I thought it would be.  I also wasnt bowled over by it as a Strong Ale. I think it was because of the aforementioned balance.  The rye was definately understated in the finish. Much more likely to revisit than any other of this style.

Granted this isnt a real popular style for most of us on this site. But of the beers within the style, this isnt bad.  I got this one weekend when our local Mexican joint ran out of Negra Modelo.  Thinking Corona when I ordered it, I was pleasantly surprised.  No,  it hasnt become of a favorite but "in case of emergency" taking internally is acceptable.
